title: Why don't some people listen to the lyrics of songs? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s a few reasons. I think it’s mostly get caught up in the melody and the beat and just go along with it and don’t take the time to process the lyrics through our language centers in our brains. Simply put, we are hearing the lyrics, but not listening to them. In other words, we do not engage with the music (as we would in an active conversation) but we just passively hear it. For example, I recall way back when the song “Brick” by Ben Folds Five was on the radio (1997: I just looked it up). I probably listened to it for a full two or three months (off and on on the radio or the video was on TV) before I suddenly paused and really listened to the lyrics and suddenly realized it was about a guy taking his girlfriend to get an abortion the day after Christmas. Wow. Didn’t change my appreciation for the song, but I was suddenly more mindful about what he (and other songs) were saying. BTW: Back in the old days, radios weren’t as good as they are now. It was a little harder to hear the lyrics. For example (and this is a big one): I saw the movie Grease when it came out in the theaters. It was one of my sister’s all-time favorite movies. She played the soundtrack nonstop one summer. Then, decades later, my wife and I go to the Grease Sing-Along movie (the movie with animated song lyrics on the screen: if you get a chance to see it, go – the lyrics are well done and funny). And then the lyrics for “Greased Lightning” come on the screen. I had “heard” this song countless times. And this was the first time I realized just how dirty those lyrics are. “You know it ain’t no sh*t we’ll be getting lots of tit in greased lightning… you are supreme, the chicks will cream… you know I ain’t braggin’ she’s a really pussy wagon… greased lightning.” WOWZA. Quite an eye opener, I must say!
